dcterms:title: Landscape of somatic mutations in aging human heart muscle cells
dcterms:abstract: Using single-cell whole-genome sequencing, we identified and characterized the landscape of somatic single-nucleotide variants (sSNVs) in single cardiomyocytes from individuals across the human lifespan. Aged cardiomyocytes were found to have a higher burden of sSNVs and show mutational signatures that suggest failed repair of oxidative DNA damage.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The introduction discusses the significance of aging as a risk factor for heart diseases and highlights the gap in understanding the mechanisms of aging in cardiomyocytes.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Methods
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: We evaluated the landscape of somatic single-nucleotide variants (sSNVs) in aging cardiomyocytes using advanced single-cell whole-genome sequencing.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Results
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Our analysis revealed a significantly higher burden of sSNVs in aged cardiomyocytes with specific mutational signatures related to oxidative stress.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Discussion
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The findings suggest that accumulated somatic mutations in cardiomyocytes are linked to age-related dysfunction in heart tissue.
